WRITING.TEXT:
Not quite.
Le Pen is different from Trump. For one, the Le Pen name has loomed over French politics for what seems like forever. She is an established politician. Not only that, but Le Pen's economic policies are alien to the ideas thought up by the GOP. Le Pen can at least pay lip service to the welfare state.
Macron also has difference from Clinton. For one, he is much younger with much less experience. And he isn't running as part of an establishment party, his is brand new.
And Melenchon- he isn't even close to Bernie. Bernie in France would be considered establishment left. Melenchon is far to the left, a staunch anti-capitalist.
Also, Le Pen doesn't really have a chance. I know people like to talk about how the polls are all wrong, but she's like 20 points behind. To be that far off would be unprecedented, a whole different league from Brexit or Trump. And Macron doesn't have to worry about having the election stolen from him by an undemocratic electoral system.
Honestly, it seems to me like Americans like to see every global event as an extension of their own country. Not everything is a parallel to America.

I hate how everything requires a constitutional amendment to change, but constitutional amendments are borderline impossible to push through. Seriously, I honestly wish we could get a new constitution because our system is in serious need of reform in all areas.

The number of people I know who understand nothing from Orwell and just think it means socialism=bad is just astounding. People fail to realise George Orwell was an anti-capitalist, and never intended to have his works interpreted as support for capitalism. Anyway, people forget that the main target of his criticism was authoritarianism in general.

The only thing I could think of is maybe in an alternate timeline slaves are mainly taken from only Muslim sections of West Africa, and a lot more of them are taken by the slave trade. If enough slaves were imported, they could become a majority in a couple of southern states, but I don't see that realistically happening. If this was the case though, you would obviously see more numerous and successful slave revolts, weakening the confederacy significantly. This would probably be occurring even before the Civil War. This could have been an effective strategy if slaves were so numerous.

WRITING.TITLE: I tried to redraw the River Gee County Flag on MS Paint

WRITING.TEXT: First, the Portuguese Restoration War would have to have never happened, and the Iberian Union survives, with its members fully integrated. The French phase of the Thirty Years' War goes terribly wrong for France, and Spain is able to take southern portions of France in the 1640s. The Peace of Westphalia goes very well for them, although they begrudgingly release the Netherlands, fed up with obnoxious rebellions. Meanwhile, many of Europe's Protestant states have been forcibly converted back. Spain has made itself into an even greater power, and now is the most powerful in Europe. France is weakened severely, and has lost most of its Mediterranean coast. They probably never take Corsica in this scenario, and Genoa has it for the moment. Sometime over the next hundred years, Naples either goes free or goes to Austria. It is possible that in this timeline, Italian nationalists reach out to Spain for help instead of France in the mid 1800s, letting Spain keep Sicily and Sardinia, and giving them Corsica. Later, since Spain is still the greatest colonial power and was never trampled by Napoleon, they get a large chunk out of North Africa. The Sahel is basically there's for the taking, and they've made significant gains even before the scramble for Africa.

Well, considering Gran Colombia didn't even stay together, and Bolivar wasn't the one who liberated Argentina(San Martin) or Chile(O'Higgins), an empire from Panama to Patagonia would be an incredible challenge.
But, if Gran Colombia stayed together (not too unfeasible), but with Bolivar as its monarch, I can definitely see the easy acquisition of Bolivia and Peru. The biggest challenge comes with Argentina and Chile. It would really all depend on how genuinely sincere their leaders were about Latin American nationalism, and how willing they were to disregard republicanism. But, since this is a hypothetical, let's just say Chile and La Plata both saw it in their interest to join with Bolivar.
This new Empire would become the greatest power in the New World, given time to consolidate. It would probably wage frequent wars with Brasil, usually winning, in an attempt to unite South America. It's hard to say how they would interact with the US or Europe. Regardless, if they could stay together, they would become a full-fledged power at the level of Europe's powerful states. They may not be as active in international affairs, taking an isolationist approach like the US.

1 horse, but it has to be alive. If it dies while you are eating it, you gain a fraction of 1 horsepower proportional to the fraction of the horse you ate. WRITING.TEXT: So, my high school MUN club organised a small middle school conference every year, and this year they've promoted me to chair since I've tended to perform better than most club members, despite having only been to 4 conferences (3 of which I won an award). WRITING.TITLE: What if Gran Colombia and La Plata had both stayed united
WRITING.TEXT: So, if the Latin American countries of the time never fragmented into the countries we know today, how would it have effected the state of Latin America, and the world?

All of Latin America split from Spain, and then a bunch of other smaller countries split from those countries. La Plata split into Argentina, Uruguay, Bolivia, and Paraguay. Gran Colombia split into Colombia, Venezuela, and Ecuador, and Panama split from Colombia later on. There have been quite a lot, that's just one example.

Well, I would guess that if the American Revolution never happened, the colonists would end up in a situation similar to Canada, with devolved autonomy by the mid 1800s. They might have even been incorporated into the same entity as the dominion of Canada, and the Eastern US and Canada fully independent as one country after WWII. Probably the Northwest as well, since Britain would likely still have been interested in that territory, and taken them easily without serious competition. Mexico might still have the SW US, assuming no conflict analogous to the Mexican-American War happened.

WRITING.TITLE: What if the Ming dynasty had discovered America
WRITING.TEXT: Around the time of the Ming, they were sending around massive fleets at far as East Africa to exact tribute. So what if they would have looked to the east and found America before Columbus? Would it be feasible? How would that turn out? Would they establish colonies like Europe, or default to their historical tendencies to establish vassals/ tributary states? If they did establish colonies, how would they respond to dynastic changes, particularly the fall of the Ming?

Heh. I found that joke particularly funny, being from Florida.
To answer your question, the Normans of Northern France are different because they actually come from Scandinavian descent. The Vikings began raiding the area around 800 CE. In 911 CE, the Franks agreed to recognise the Dutchy of Normandy, lead by Rollo. Over time, the Scandinavians who lived there sort of integrated into the French population. As far as surnames go, having a Norman one as opposed to a French one means it probably come more from Scandinavia. Hope that helps.

WRITING.TITLE: How did the Mongol empire maintain its massive size?
WRITING.TEXT:
Besides the Mongols, it seems every other empire in the times when horseback was the quickest form of communication, that basically every other empire reached a limit and were unable to expand beyond, due to the hassle of keeping together such far flung territories.
Yet the Mongols took most of Asia before splitting into fragments. The effect was delayed, and they somehow managed to keep them long enough to conquer the continent. I've heard a few explanations for this. The Mongols were incredible in the art of intimidation, so their ruthlessness might have deterred potential rebellions. I've also heard about the role their religious tolerance and general acceptance of other cultures(except Chinese culture) sort of kept it together. Yet it seems like both of those could apply to others. Many other central Asian empires were about as ruthless, and the Achaemenids were renowned for their religious tolerance and effective bureaucracy, something the Mongols, to my knowledge, were totally lacking in.
So, what made Mongolia the exception as opposed to other groups with similar characteristics and/or superior governing structures?
